segment.source: BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature that integrates with the operating system and addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.
segment.target: BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature that integrates with the operating system and addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.

segment.source: BitLocker provides the most protection when used with a Trusted Platform Module (TPM) version 1.2 or later.
segment.target: BitLocker provides the most protection when used with a Trusted Platform Module (TPM) version 1.2 or later.

segment.source: The TPM is a hardware component installed in many newer computers by the computer manufacturers.
segment.target: The TPM is a hardware component installed in many newer computers by the computer manufacturers.

segment.source: It works with BitLocker to help protect user data and to ensure that a computer has not been tampered with while the system was offline.
segment.target: It works with BitLocker to help protect user data and to ensure that a computer has not been tampered with while the system was offline.

segment.source: On computers that do not have a TPM version 1.2 or later, you can still use BitLocker to encrypt the Windows operating system drive.
segment.target: On computers that do not have a TPM version 1.2 or later, you can still use BitLocker to encrypt the Windows operating system drive.

segment.source: However, this implementation will require the user to insert a USB startup key to start the computer or resume from hibernation.
segment.target: However, this implementation will require the user to insert a USB startup key to start the computer or resume from hibernation.

segment.source: Starting with Windows 8, you can use an operating system volume password to protect the operating system volume on a computer without TPM.
segment.target: Starting with Windows 8, you can use an operating system volume password to protect the operating system volume on a computer without TPM.

segment.source: Both options do not provide the pre-startup system integrity verification offered by BitLocker with a TPM.
segment.target: Both options do not provide the pre-startup system integrity verification offered by BitLocker with a TPM.

segment.source: In addition to the TPM, BitLocker offers the option to lock the normal startup process until the user supplies a personal identification number (PIN) or inserts a removable device, such as a USB flash drive, that contains a startup key.
segment.target: In addition to the TPM, BitLocker offers the option to lock the normal startup process until the user supplies a personal identification number (PIN) or inserts a removable device, such as a USB flash drive, that contains a startup key.

segment.source: These additional security measures provide multifactor authentication and assurance that the computer will not start or resume from hibernation until the correct PIN or startup key is presented.
segment.target: These additional security measures provide multifactor authentication and assurance that the computer will not start or resume from hibernation until the correct PIN or startup key is presented.

segment.source: Practical applications
segment.target: Practical applications

segment.source: Data on a lost or stolen computer is vulnerable to unauthorized access, either by running a software-attack tool against it or by transferring the computer's hard disk to a different computer.
segment.target: Data on a lost or stolen computer is vulnerable to unauthorized access, either by running a software-attack tool against it or by transferring the computer's hard disk to a different computer.

segment.source: BitLocker helps mitigate unauthorized data access by enhancing file and system protections.
segment.target: BitLocker helps mitigate unauthorized data access by enhancing file and system protections.

segment.source: BitLocker also helps render data inaccessible when BitLocker-protected computers are decommissioned or recycled.
segment.target: BitLocker also helps render data inaccessible when BitLocker-protected computers are decommissioned or recycled.

segment.source: There are two additional tools in the Remote Server Administration Tools, which you can use to manage BitLocker.
segment.target: There are two additional tools in the Remote Server Administration Tools, which you can use to manage BitLocker.

segment.source: BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer.
segment.target: BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer.

segment.source: The BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer enables you to locate and view BitLocker Drive Encryption recovery passwords that have been backed up to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).
segment.target: The BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer enables you to locate and view BitLocker Drive Encryption recovery passwords that have been backed up to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).

segment.source: You can use this tool to help recover data that is stored on a drive that has been encrypted by using BitLocker.
segment.target: You can use this tool to help recover data that is stored on a drive that has been encrypted by using BitLocker.

segment.source: The BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer tool is an extension for the Active Directory Users and Computers Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in.
segment.target: The BitLocker Recovery Password Viewer tool is an extension for the Active Directory Users and Computers Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in.

segment.source: By using this tool, you can examine a computer object's Properties dialog box to view the corresponding BitLocker recovery passwords.
segment.target: By using this tool, you can examine a computer object's Properties dialog box to view the corresponding BitLocker recovery passwords.

segment.source: Additionally, you can right-click a domain container and then search for a BitLocker recovery password across all the domains in the Active Directory forest.
segment.target: Additionally, you can right-click a domain container and then search for a BitLocker recovery password across all the domains in the Active Directory forest.

segment.source: To view recovery passwords, you must be a domain administrator, or you must have been delegated permissions by a domain administrator.
segment.target: To view recovery passwords, you must be a domain administrator, or you must have been delegated permissions by a domain administrator.

segment.source: BitLocker Drive Encryption Tools.
segment.target: BitLocker Drive Encryption Tools.

segment.source: BitLocker Drive Encryption Tools include the command-line tools, manage-bde and repair-bde, and the BitLocker cmdlets for Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: BitLocker Drive Encryption Tools include the command-line tools, manage-bde and repair-bde, and the BitLocker cmdlets for Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: Both manage-bde and the BitLocker cmdlets can be used to perform any task that can be accomplished through the BitLocker control panel, and they are appropriate to use for automated deployments and other scripting scenarios.
segment.target: Both manage-bde and the BitLocker cmdlets can be used to perform any task that can be accomplished through the BitLocker control panel, and they are appropriate to use for automated deployments and other scripting scenarios.

segment.source: Repair-bde is provided for disaster recovery scenarios in which a BitLocker protected drive cannot be unlocked normally or by using the recovery console.
segment.target: Repair-bde is provided for disaster recovery scenarios in which a BitLocker protected drive cannot be unlocked normally or by using the recovery console.

segment.source: System requirements
segment.target: System requirements

segment.source: BitLocker has the following hardware requirements:
segment.target: BitLocker has the following hardware requirements:

segment.source: For BitLocker to use the system integrity check provided by a Trusted Platform Module (TPM), the computer must have TPM 1.2 or later.
segment.target: For BitLocker to use the system integrity check provided by a Trusted Platform Module (TPM), the computer must have TPM 1.2 or later.

segment.source: If your computer does not have a TPM, enabling BitLocker requires that you save a startup key on a removable device, such as a USB flash drive.
segment.target: If your computer does not have a TPM, enabling BitLocker requires that you save a startup key on a removable device, such as a USB flash drive.

segment.source: A computer with a TPM must also have a Trusted Computing Group (TCG)-compliant BIOS or UEFI firmware.
segment.target: A computer with a TPM must also have a Trusted Computing Group (TCG)-compliant BIOS or UEFI firmware.

segment.source: The BIOS or UEFI firmware establishes a chain of trust for the pre-operating system startup, and it must include support for TCG-specified Static Root of Trust Measurement.
segment.target: The BIOS or UEFI firmware establishes a chain of trust for the pre-operating system startup, and it must include support for TCG-specified Static Root of Trust Measurement.

segment.source: A computer without a TPM does not require TCG-compliant firmware.
segment.target: A computer without a TPM does not require TCG-compliant firmware.

segment.source: The system BIOS or UEFI firmware (for TPM and non-TPM computers) must support the USB mass storage device class, including reading small files on a USB flash drive in the pre-operating system environment.
segment.target: The system BIOS or UEFI firmware (for TPM and non-TPM computers) must support the USB mass storage device class, including reading small files on a USB flash drive in the pre-operating system environment.

segment.source: The hard disk must be partitioned with at least two drives:
segment.target: The hard disk must be partitioned with at least two drives:

segment.source: The operating system drive (or boot drive) contains the operating system and its support files.
segment.target: The operating system drive (or boot drive) contains the operating system and its support files.

segment.source: It must be formatted with the NTFS file system.
segment.target: It must be formatted with the NTFS file system.

segment.source: The system drive contains the files that are needed to load Windows after the firmware has prepared the system hardware.
segment.target: The system drive contains the files that are needed to load Windows after the firmware has prepared the system hardware.

segment.source: BitLocker is not enabled on this drive.
segment.target: BitLocker is not enabled on this drive.

segment.source: For BitLocker to work, the system drive must not be encrypted, must differ from the operating system drive, and must be formatted with the FAT32 file system on computers that use UEFI-based firmware or with the NTFS file system on computers that use BIOS firmware.
segment.target: For BitLocker to work, the system drive must not be encrypted, must differ from the operating system drive, and must be formatted with the FAT32 file system on computers that use UEFI-based firmware or with the NTFS file system on computers that use BIOS firmware.

segment.source: We recommend that system drive be approximately 350 MB in size.
segment.target: We recommend that system drive be approximately 350 MB in size.

segment.source: After BitLocker is turned on it should have approximately 250 MB of free space.
segment.target: After BitLocker is turned on it should have approximately 250 MB of free space.

segment.source: When installed on a new computer, Windows will automatically create the partitions that are required for BitLocker.
segment.target: When installed on a new computer, Windows will automatically create the partitions that are required for BitLocker.

segment.source: When installing the BitLocker optional component on a server you will also need to install the Enhanced Storage feature, which is used to support hardware encrypted drives.
segment.target: When installing the BitLocker optional component on a server you will also need to install the Enhanced Storage feature, which is used to support hardware encrypted drives.
